abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Pathogenic variants in<jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>have been classically thought to cause Li-Fraumeni syndrome (LFS), a cancer predisposition with high risks for various childhood- and adult-onset malignancies. However, increased genetic testing has lately revealed, that pathogenic variant carriers exhibit a broader range of phenotypes and that penetrance may be dependent both on variant type and modifiers. Using next generation sequencing and short tandem repeat analysis, we identified germline pathogenic variants in<jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>RAD51C</jats:italic>located in<jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>on chromosome 17 in a 43-year-old male, who has developed a rare sebaceous gland carcinoma (SGC) but so far no tumors of the LFS spectrum. This course mirrors a<jats:italic>Trp53</jats:italic>-<jats:italic>Rad51c</jats:italic>-double-mutant<jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>mouse-model, which similarly develops SGC, while the characteristic<jats:italic>Trp53</jats:italic>-associated tumor spectrum occurs with significantly lower frequency. Therefore, we propose that co-occurent pathogenic variants in<jats:italic>RAD51C</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>may predispose to SGC, reminiscent of Muir-Torre syndrome. Further, this report supports the diversity of clinical presentations associated with germline<jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>alterations, and thus, the proposed expansion of LFS to heritable<jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic>-related cancer syndrome.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: This study was approved by the ethics committee of the University of Leipzig, Germany (224/16-ek and 402/16-ek). Informed consent was obtained from each tested individual prior to genetic testing (for thorough description and discussion of ethical and management aspects see Supplementary Material).

title: In cis TP53 and RAD51C pathogenic variants may predispose to sebaceous gland carcinomas
